author: potuz
content: That applies to this particular case and network, although all rollups that I'm aware of have planned side chains and are similar companies to polygon. There is some blame to put on the user that decides to move coins on BSC if Binance robs them eventually. But this does not apply to users of polygon, as far as users are concerned everything indicates they were putting their money on a legitimate project. It is something very worrisome when legitimate projects get hacked like this, and when they get hacked so often. Are we expecting users not to use any of these projects or do users need to be security experts and try to find bugs themselves? I'm aware that bugs will always be there, but the frequency of these hacks is a different level and I'd argue that is a concern for the core protocol. Although I concede that there's probably nothing that can be done at the core level, perhaps something can be done at the human level, several of these projects get grants from the EF, perhaps it would be good to encourage **not** to deploy contracts too soon

author: sky.cactus
content:
> But this does not apply to users of polygon, as far as users are concerned everything indicates they were putting their money on a legitimate project. 
Everything except the legitimate security experts in the field telling people explicitly to not put their money into Polygon...

author: sky.cactus
content: Polygon is a 5/9 multisig to instantly liquidate everything.  This is not censorship resistant at all, it is just a centralized side chain masquerading as a layer 2 solution.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Are we expecting users not to use any of these projects or do users need to be security experts and try to find bugs themselves?
What would be nice is if users learned that they shouldn't believe everything people slap on a website and instead should build up and utilize a more reliable trust network to gain information on who to trust.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> I concede that there's probably nothing that can be done at the core level, perhaps something can be done at the human level, several of these projects get grants from the EF, perhaps it would be good to encourage not to deploy contracts too soon
The EF can do what it wants with its money.  I would love to see the EF become more insistent that grant recipients must build something that aligns with the ethos of Ethereum, which *at least* means not claiming to be L2 if you are really just a custodial solution.

author: sky.cactus
content: If Polygon wants to build something that is *eventually* censorship resistant that is one thing, but I do find it distasteful that they advertise as an L2 solution just because they plan to *eventually* be an L2 solution.
